author: Megan Palin
title: AFL Grand Final eve public holiday | What about the rest of us?
text:
THE state of Victoria gets a bit of a sleep in today, because there is a grand final tomorrow.
That’s right, those lucky ones that get to skip work on Melbourne Cup Day in November also have today off as it is the AFL grand final eve.
But what about the rest of us? Shouldn’t all those rugby league fans in NSW and Queensland get a ‘Friday before the NRL Grand Final’ public holiday each year?
Victoria is the public holiday capital of Australia after the Labor Government announced holidays for AFL Grand Final eve and Easter Sunday.
Grand Final Friday, alone, is predicted to cost at least $800 million in wages, lost productivity and penalty rates.
Half of Melbourne’s restaurants are expected to close on Grand Final Friday with ­penalty rates at double time and a half, giving visitors to the city few options to eat.
According to the Australian Industry Group, every leisurely free holiday in Australia costs the national economy between $3 and $4 billion , and for business owners the personal costs are enormous.
Chief executive of Australian Industry Group Innes Willox said the disparity in public holiday schedules across the states was hurting businesses and the national economy.
“Lack of synchronisation across the country is certainly costly and inconvenient, especially for businesses with a national presence or who operate across state borders,” he said in a statement to news.com.au.
A battle over public holidays certainly isn’t new to Australia, and is regularly cause for debate.
TERRITORY DAY/CRACKER NIGHT, NORTHERN TERRITORY
This is the one time a year that Territorians are allowed to do something most Australians cannot — and when they do, they go a little Troppo.
This rare privilege — to let off fireworks on July 1 each year — is in honour of the Northern Territory finally achieving self-governance.
For a brief few hours on July 1 every year, Territorians are allowed to go off, quite literally, with a big bang.
The tradition has been in place since 1980 after the then government declared the Top End needed another “cracker night” that honoured an occasion more relevant to locals.
Previously, they had celebrated Guy Fawkes Day in November. Territory Day seemed more appropriate. However the annual event is not loved by everyone.
Some Territorians loathe the tradition and would rather see the back end of it.
Besides anti-social behaviour, locals also have to worry about rogue fireworks setting off fires and damaging properties.
Territory night was alight at the annual Mindil Beach Territory Day fireworks display. Source: News Corp Australia
The NT Government recently surveyed the public on whether or not Territory Day should become a public holiday.
Chief Minister Adam Giles said the public voted about 50/50 but “slightly in favour” of the holiday but in doing so taking away an existing one.
“I had floated the idea of making Territory Day a public holiday by swapping it with an existing one but Territorians were divided,” he said.
“It is clear at this point in time that there isn’t a strong enough desire from the community to create a public holiday to celebrate Territory Day.”
PEOPLE’S DAY, QUEENSLAND
Going to the Ekka is a rite of passage for Queenslanders who watch pig racing and visit cake stalls and buy show bags as part of the event.
The Ekka is marked with a public holiday, known as People’s Day, in August each year. It’s Queensland’s biggest annual event which attracts more than 50,000 people.
But many have argued that it should fall on a weekend and not be a public holiday.
Queensland Treasurer and Minister for Industrial Relations Curtis Pitt said the Brisbane public holiday falls in the middle of the week at the request of the show’s organiser.
“The RNA requests the Wednesday as its show day each year,” he said in a statement. “Wednesday is the traditional show day holiday for the Brisbane region — the community knows and understands this.”
Mr Pitt says there were no plans for a change.
Down on the farm at Calvary Christian College Carbrook. Mikaela Williams with Pickles who won first prize at the Ekka. Picture: Paul Guy Source: News Corp Australia
MELBOURNE CUP DAY, VICTORIA
It’s a day marked with a public holiday in Victoria, but many Australians in other states want the ‘race that stops the nation’ to become a national public holiday.
Those in favour of a national Melbourne Cup Day argue that the event costs Australia more than $1 billion in lost productivity anyway so should be swapped with another public holiday.
There has been discussion over whether a Melbourne Cup Day should replace the Queen’s Birthday holiday, according to a new poll.
An exclusive Sunday Mail poll showed 47 per cent of those surveyed favoured the move from a June day off to the first Tuesday of November, while 46 per cent were against the move.
Another 7 per cent were uncommitted.
However, there was a clear difference of opinion between young and old.
Those 18-49 years of age were 53 per cent in favour of replacing the birthday holiday with the Melbourne Cup, while 53 per cent of the over-50s were against the proposal.
Racing — 2014 Melbourne Cup Day. Race 7 Emirates Melbourne Cup. Winner no. 5 Protectionist ridden by Ryan Moore. Picture: Tim Carrafa Source: News Corp Australia
